awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Algebra and Geometry Behind Link Homology
awd_abstract_narration:
The Hecke algebra and its generalizations are central objects in modern representation theory. They naturally appear in number theory, representation theory, algebraic geometry, and even low-dimensional topology. A categorification of the Hecke algebra was used to define a new topological invariant of knots and links, known as HOMFLY-PT homology. However, it is extremely difficult to compute this invariant from the definition. The project is focused on understanding the algebraic, geometric, and combinatorial structure of link homology and categorified Hecke algebras, with the goal of unifying, deepening, and clarifying connections between these concepts.

Recent progress strongly indicates a connection between the HOMFLY-PT homology and algebraic geometry of the Hilbert scheme of points on the plane, a central object in modern algebraic geometry and geometric representation theory.  In this collaborative project, the investigators plan to compare and unify different approaches to the study of this connection and to develop the fundamental understanding of the relation between the category of Soergel bimodules and the Hilbert scheme. They also plan to provide an algebro-geometric construction of HOMFLY-PT homology and to understand its relation to the combinatorics of Macdonald polynomials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of the project was to investigate a relation between the HOMFLY-PT link homology based on Soergel bimodules, and affine Nakajima quiver varieties, in particular, Hilbert schemes of points on C2. I also wanted to connect this relation to dualities of the String theory in view of the previously established relation between the link homology and superstrings.

The investigation showed that:

  1. The 2-category associated with a Hilbert scheme of n points on C2 yields triply graded (HOMFLY-PT) link homology as well as gl(N) homology and even the superalgebra gl(M|N) homology. The key ingredient is a homomorphism from the braid group to the monoidal category of endomorphisms of a special object related to flag varieties.
  2. The triply graded and gl(N) homologies match those constructed with the help of Soergel bimodules.
  3. A closed braid determines a complex of coherent sheaves over the Hilbert scheme, whose hypercohomology matches the homology of the link corresponding to its closure.
  4. The extension of the Hilbert scheme construction to moduli spaces of instantons on C2 yields a categorification of the cyclotomic Hecke algebra. A topological interpretation of the homology of braid closures requires a further investigation.
  5. The Hilbert scheme construction of link homology yields a relatively simple and natural proof of the “palindrome” symmetry of the knot homology.
  6. The 2-category of the Hilbert scheme emerges within the framework of the Gukov-Shwarz-Vafa superstring construction of link homology. It reflects the topological quantum field theory describing vibrations of a stack of D2 branes sitting above the North pole of the resolved conifold.
  7. A similar 2-categorical approach to Witten’s construction of superstring based link homology should yield most of currently known coherent sheaf based constructions of link homologies. This approach requires further investigation.

Thus I was able to introduce a new 2-category based approach to link homology and relate it to Superstring physics.
